EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

FOR THE 2015 RE-SUBMISSION OF THE

MAGNA Water District

Waste Water Treatment Plant

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN



This Risk Management Plan (RMP) sets forth the procedures, methods, and equipment used to prevent significant releases of chlorine from the Magna Water District (the District), Waste Water Treatment Plant (WWTP), located at 7650 West 2100 South in Magna, Utah 84044.  The RMP is required per the provisions of Part 68 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), because chlorine is used in the WWTP process in a quantity exceeding the 2,500 pound threshold listed in 40CFR 68.130.



The RMP identifies processes from which a potential chlorine release may occur.  In addition, the RMP describes the practices that are being used to reduce the likelihood of accidents and communicates compliance with the terms and conditions of the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions set forth in 40CFR Part 68.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

Process safety and emergency response procedures have been implemented at the DistrictA?s WWTP to minimize or eliminate the impacts from emergencies and/or accidents.  Emergency response plans are fully reviewed and supported by the DistrictA?s management and the RMP coordinator.



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

The DistrictA?s WWTP is a sewage treatment plant that treats raw sewage to secondary effluent standards.  Chlorine is used at the DistrictA?s WWTP to disinfect the effluent prior to discharge. The chlorine is stored as a liquid under pressure in two one-ton cylinders.  There are no other chemicals stored at the site above the threshold quantities listed in 40CFR 68.130.  



Accidental Release Prevention Program:

The potential for discharges of hazardous substances from this facility is minimal.  The DistrictA?s WWTP strictly adheres to good housekeeping, materials management practices, and training practices in order to prevent incidents.  Al

l releases are to be mitigated immediately.  Materials and equipment necessary for prompt spill clean-up are kept on-site.  



Five-year Accident History:

The facility has not experienced a significant release, spill, or leak of any toxic pollutant, or hazardous material, or experienced an injury as result of a release in the past five years.



Emergency Response Program:

All aspects of the Emergency Response Program have been coordinated with the Salt Lake County Fire Department.  If a release occurs, employees have been trained to take corrective and clean-up actions and notify the RMP coordinator so that he can determine if the spill should be reported to the appropriate agency. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Monthly meetings are held with all employees to review and improve existing safety procedures.
